metadata.title: Stress-driven nonlocal integral elasticity for axisymmetric nano-plates

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
International Journal of Engineering Science
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/ijengsci
Stress-driven nonlocal integral elasticity for axisymmetric
nano-plates
R. Barretta a , ∗, S. Ali Faghidian b , F. Marotti de Sciarra a
a Department of Structures for Engineering and Architecture, University of Naples Federico II, via Claudio 21, 80125 Naples, Italy b Department of Mechanical Engineering, Science and Research Branch, Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Iran
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 19 December 2018 Revised 27 January 2019 Accepted 29 January 2019
Keywords: Nano-plates Size effects Integral elasticity Stress-driven nonlocal laws Reissner variational principle Analytical modelling CNT NEMS
a b s t r a c t
The stress-driven nonlocal integral model of elasticity for 1D nano-structures (Romano & Barretta, 2017a) is extended in this paper to Kirchhoff axisymmetric nano-plates. The nonlocal formulation, relating elastic principal flexural curvatures and moments, provides an effective methodology to assess size effects in 2D nano-structures. The associated elastostatic problem of nano-plates is conveniently expressed by differential relations equipped with constitutive boundary conditions involving nonlocal curvature fields. The proposed approach is illustrated by examining case-studies of engineering interest. In particular, nonlocal displacement solutions of axisymmetric nano-plates are detected for a variety of loading systems and kinematic boundary conditions. Merits and implications of the stressdriven strategy are elucidated by comparing the achieved results with those of the strain gradient model of elasticity generated by Reissner’s variational principle. The outcomes can be useful for design and optimization of plate-like components of ground-breaking NanoElectro-Mechanical-Systems (NEMS).
© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nano-engineering materials and modern devices of nanotechnological interest reveal technically significant size-effects, whose structural modelling requires inclusion of suitable scale parameters in constitutive relations. Size-dependent continuum theories of elasticity are still on the main focus of numerous researches to explain and assess nano-scale phenomena. Thin plate continuum models are widely employed in design and analysis of Nano-Electro-Mechanical Systems (NEMS) ( Ramsden, 2016; Zhang and Hoshino, 2014 ), due to their simplicity and computational advantages in comparison with atomistic/hybrid methodologies. Nowadays nano-plates are basic structural elements of nano-devices, such as gas sensors ( Kalanur, Yoo, & Seo, 2017; Shendage et al., 2017 ), electrochemical sensors ( Li et al., 2018a; Medina, Gilat, & Krylov, 2018 ), photo-transistors ( Zhang et al., 2018 ), bio-sensors ( Ogi, Iwagami, Nagakubo, Taniguchi, & Ono, 2019; Yokokura, Nakashima, Yonemoto, Hikichi, & Nakanishi, 2017 ), super-capacitors ( Chen et al., 2019; Nath et al., 2019; Yesuraj, Suthanthiraraj, & Padmaraj, 2019 ), mass sensors ( Askari, Jamshidifar, & Fidan, 2017; Fernández-Sáez, Morassi, Rubioc, & Zaera, 2019; Rajabi & Hosseini-Hashemi, 2018 ), scanning electron microscope ( Caplins, Holm, & Keller, 2019 ) and strain sensors ( Zhang, Wu, Peng, Sha, & Wang, 2019 ). A series of recent contributions on structural modelling of NEMS can be found in the literature of Engineering Science as follows. Free vibrations of nano-rods ( Numano ̆glu, Akgöz, & Civalek, 2018 ), postbuckling behavior of nanotubes ( She, Yuan, Ren, & Xiao, 2017 ) and size-dependent wrinkling hierarchy in graphene ( Zhao, Guo, & Lu, 2018 ) have
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: rabarret@unina.it (R. Barretta), faghidian@gmail.com , faghidian@srbiau.ac.ir (S.A. Faghidian), marotti@unina.it (F. Marotti de Sciarra).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijengsci.2019.01.003 0020-7225/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
been recently examined employing Eringen’s nonlocal differential law. Eringen-like integral nonlocal models have been also used to investigate axial statics ( Acierno, Barretta, Luciano, Marotti de Sciarra, & Russo, 2017 ), flexure ( Fernández-Sáez, Zaera, Loya, & Reddy, 2016 ), free vibrations ( Fernández-Sáez & Zaera, 2017; Khaniki, 2018 , 2019 ) and buckling of nano-beams ( Zhu, Wang, & Dai, 2017 ). An enhanced Eringen differential law ( Barretta, Feo, Luciano, Marotti de Sciarra, & Penna, 2016a,b ) has been also employed for studying torsion ( Apuzzo et al., 2017a ) and flexure of nano-beams ( Demir & Civalek, 2017 ).
Elastic solids reinforced with bidirectional fibers ( Kim & Zeidi, 2018 ), pure bending problems of beams ( Lurie & Solyaev, 2018 ), flexure of slender nano-beams ( Barretta, Brcic, Canadija, Luciano, & Marotti de Sciarra, 2017 ), free vibrations of nano-beams ( Hadi, ZamaniNejad, & Hosseini, 2018 ) and flexoelectric curved micro-beams ( Qi, Huang, Fu, Zhou, & Jiang, 2018 ) have been furthermore inspected by strain gradient elasticity laws. The modified couple stress theory has been likewise exploited to estimate dynamic responses ( Attia & Abdel Rahman, 2018; Ghayesh, 2018 , 2019; Ghayesh & Farokhi, 2018 ) and stability of nano-structures ( Jiao & Alavi, 2018; Taati, 2018 ).
Consistent with the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity model, flexure ( Li, Tang, & Hu, 2018b ), vibrations ( Lu, Guo, & Zhao, 2017 ) of nano-beams, tension of nano-rods ( Zhu & Li, 2017a , b ), dynamics of nano-tubes ( Ghayesh & Farajpour, 2018; Ghayesh, Farokhi, & Farajpour, 2019 ) and wave propagation and vibrations of porous nano-tubes ( She, Ren, Yuan, & Xiao, 2018a , b ) as well as curved nanotubes ( She, Yuan, Karami, Ren, & Xiao, 2019 ) have been explored. In the framework of the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory, the Reissner variational principle has been lately proposed ( Faghidian, 2018a ) and employed to introduce the Reissner beam model ( Faghidian, 2018b ). A second-order integro-differential nonlocal theory was also contributed by a thermodynamic approach ( Faghidian, 2018c ) to include higher-order strain gradient effects within Eringen integral nonlocal theory. The modified nonlocal strain gradient model of elasticity has been established by Barretta and Marotti de Sciarra (2018) introducing the appropriate constitutive boundary conditions to be prescribed to close the constitutive model for bounded nano-structures. Such a theory has been effectively adopted to examine axial and flexural free vibrations of Bernoulli–Euler nano-beams ( Apuzzo, Barretta, Faghidian, Luciano, & Marotti de Sciarra, 2018a ). A variety of size-dependent theories of elasticity have been employed in literature to study nano-plates subjected to flexure including the Eringen differential nonlocal model ( Despotovic, 2018; Khaniki & Hosseini-Hashemi, 2017; Li, Liu, Cheng, & Fan, 2017; Srividhya, Raghu, Rajagopal, & Reddy, 2018 ), strain gradient theory ( Gousias & Lazopoulos, 2015; Ji, Li, & Zhou, 2017; Lazopoulos, 20 04, 20 09; Mirsalehi, Azhari, & Amoushahi, 2017; Mousavi & Paavola, 2014; Papargyri-Beskou & Beskos, 2008; Papargyri-Beskou, Giannakopoulos, & Beskos, 2010 ), modified couple stress theory ( Barati & Shahverdi, 2017; Farokhi & Ghayesh, 2018; Farokhi, Ghayesh, Gholipour, & Tavallaeinejad, 2017; Rahaeifard & Mojahedi, 2017 ) and nonlocal strain gradient laws ( Ebrahimi, Barati, & Dabbagh, 2016; Lu, Guo, & Zhao, 2018; Shahverdi & Barati, 2017 ). Reviews on the mechanics of nanostructures have been provided in ( Farajpour, Ghayesh, & Farokhi, 2018; Ghayesh & Farajpour,

According to the strain-driven Eringen integral model (EIM), the stress field is the convolution of the elastic strain field with an appropriate kernel function ( Eringen, 1983 ). In Eringen’s purely nonlocal problems defined on unbounded domains, the integral convolution is a Fredholm equation of the first type. It can be replaced with a more convenient differential equation, named Eringen differential nonlocal model (EDM), due to tacit fulfillment of vanishing constitutive boundary conditions at infinity. However, for nanostructures of applicative problems (defined on bounded domains), EDM is not equivalent to EIM but suitable strain-driven constitutive boundary conditions (CBC) have to be prescribed to ensure equivalence ( Romano & Barretta, 2016 ). Nevertheless, CBC conflict with equilibrium requirements and therefore these nonlocal problems are ill-posed ( Romano, Barretta, Diaco, & Marotti de Sciarra, 2017a ). Ill-posedness of elastostatic nonlocal problems governed by EIM was comprehensively discussed by Romano et al. (2017a, 2017b, 2018 ) demonstrating that EIM nonlocal problems of nano-mechanics do not admit solution for any positive value of the nonlocal parameter. A mixture made of Eringen integral model (MEIM) is a convex combination of local and EIM nonlocal phases, that is a combination with non-negative scalar coefficients summing to unity. The MEIM was adopted to resolve the ill-posedness of strain-driven nonlocal problems. However, MEIM reveals singular behaviors as the mixture is approaching the nonlocal EIM phase, thus the ill-posedness of EIM cannot be utterly removed ( Romano et al., 2017b, 2018 ).
A stress-driven nonlocal integral model (SDM) was recently introduced to nano-beams by Romano and Barretta (2017a) to resolve inconsistencies of EIM. Properties and merits of the well-posed SDM in comparison with strain-driven nonlocal models have been addressed in ( Romano and Barretta, 2017a , b ). The consistent SDM approach has been effectively exploited to analyze and describe size-dependent static and dynamic behaviors of inflected Bernoulli-Euler ( Apuzzo, Barretta, Luciano, Marotti de Sciarra, & Penna, 2017b; Barretta et al., 2018a , b,c,d,e; Mahmoudpour, Hosseini-Hashemi, & Faghidian, 2018 ) and Timoshenko elastic nano-beams ( Barretta, Luciano, Marotti de Sciarra, & Ruta, 2018f ).
A two-phase stress-driven constitutive mixture has been also recently proposed by Barretta Fabbrocino, Luciano, & Marotti de Sciarra (2018g) to examine size-dependent flexural behaviour of functionally graded nano-beams. Such a localnonlocal mixture is a convex combination of local and nonlocal phases of stress-driven type ( Romano & Barretta, 2017a ). The mixture made of stress-driven nonlocal integral model (MSDM) has been then employed for dynamic axial and torsional analyses of nano-beams ( Apuzzo et al., 2019 ). Nowadays, SDM and MSDM provide viable methodologies to design and optimize nano-structural elements of new-generation.
In the present paper, axisymmetric flexure of nano-plates is formulated by proposing a stress-driven nonlocal integral model which generalizes to nano-plates the methodology presented in Romano & Barretta (2017a) for beams. The plan is the following. Preliminary kinematic assumptions and differential conditions of equilibrium of Kirchhoff plate theory are briefly recalled in Section 2 . The stress-driven nonlocal integral model for nano-plates is formulated in Section 3 .
For comparison sake, the flexural behaviour of Kirchhoff nano-plates based on the strain gradient theory of elasticity (SGT) is then investigated in Section 4 by employing Reissner’s variational principle. Nonlocal responses of nano-plates associated with the proposed SDM are detected in Section 5 and compared with results achieved by SGT. Closing remarks are collected in Section 6 by underlying merits and advantages of SDM in comparison with classical size-dependent continuum models available in literature.

sections.heading: 2. Kirchhoff plate: local elasticity approach
sections.text:
A linearly elastic homogeneous isotropic nano-plate with annular circular cross-section of internal and external radii a and b and thickness h subjected to a distributed transverse load q is considered and illustrated in Fig. 1 . A cylindrical coordinate system ( r, θ , z ) is adopted, with the plate planform described by the rθ− plane. According to Kirchhoff’s kinematics of axisymmetric thin plates, the displacement components u r , u θ , u z are expressed by ( Timoshenko & WoinowskyKrieger, 1959 )
u r ( r, z ) = −z dw dr ( r ) , u θ ( r, z ) = 0 , u z ( r, z ) = w ( r ) (1)
where w is the transverse deflection of the mid-plane. The ensuing linearized strains write as

Radial and hoop local elastic strains ɛ rr , ɛ θθ associated with radial and hoop stress components σ rr , σθθ are expressed by
ε rr = 1 E ( σrr − νσθθ ) , ε θθ = 1 E ( σθθ − νσrr ) (5)
with E and ν Euler–Young elastic moduli and Poisson ratio. Employing the differential conditions of kinematic compatibility Eq. (2) , the local elastic law between principal curvatures and moment fields writes as
κrr = M rr − νM θθ D ( 1 − ν2 ) , κθθ = M θθ − νM rr D ( 1 − ν2 ) (6) where D = E h 3 / ( 12( 1 − ν2 ) ) is the plate flexural rigidity.

sections.heading: 3. Stress-driven nonlocal integral elasticity for nano-plates
sections.text:
The stress-driven nonlocal integral model (SDM), proposed by Romano and Barretta (2017a) for nano-beams, is extended in this section to capture size effects in axisymmetric annular elastic nano-plates. The key idea consists in formulating the nonlocal radial curvature κ rr as integral convolution of the local radial curvature field with a smoothing kernel
κrr ( r ) = ( ϕ λ ∗ (
M rr − νM θθ D ( 1 − ν2
) ) ) ( r ) = ∫ b

ϕ λ( r − ρ) M rr ( ρ) − νM θθ ( ρ) D ( 1 − ν2 ) dρ (7) with a and b internal and external radii of the plate. The non-dimensional strictly positive parameter λ is defined by the ratio
λ = L c b − a (8)
where L c is the characteristic length describing size effects. Following the seminal contribution by Eringen (1983) , the averaging kernel ϕλ in Eq. (7) is assumed to fulfill the following properties.
1. Positivity and parity
ϕ λ( r ) = ϕ λ( r ) ≥ 0 (9) 2. Normalisation ∫ + ∞
−∞ ϕ λ( r ) dr = 1 (10)
3. Impulsivity
lim λ→ 0 + ∫ + ∞ −∞ ϕ λ( r − ρ) f ( ρ) dρ = f ( r ) (11)
for any continuous test field f ( Romano et al., 2017b, 2018 ).
Following the strategy exploited in Barretta & Marotti de Sciarra (2018) , Prop. 3.1, it can be proven that the nonlocal
integral convolution Eq. (7) equipped with the special bi-exponential kernel, as depicted in Fig. 2 ,

κrr − L 2 c d 2 κrr d r 2 = M rr − νM θθ D ( 1 − ν2 ) (13) with the constitutive boundary conditions (CBC)
d κrr dr ( a ) = 1 L c κrr ( a ) −d κrr dr ( b ) = 1 L c κrr ( b ) (14)
Combining Eq. (13) with Eq. (6) 2 which expresses the circumferential curvature, we get the following stress-driven non-

The elastostatic problem of a stress-driven nonlocal nano-plate is therefore governed by a differential equation obtained by substituting Eq. (15) into the differential condition of equilibrium of Kirchhoff’s plate Eq. (3) . The differential equation governing inflected nano-plates in terms of the transverse deflection of the mid-plane w is consequently provided by

with = d 2 /d r 2 + ( 1 /r ) d /d r the Laplace operator in axisymmetric cylindrical coordinates. The boundary value problem of elastostatic flexure of a nano-plate in the framework of stress-driven nonlocal integral formulation, consists of differential and boundary conditions of equilibrium, Eqs. (16) and (3) 2,3, along with the constitutive boundary conditions Eq. (14) .
As shown in ( Romano et al., 2017a , b, 2018 ) for nano-beams, even for nano-plates, stress-driven nonlocal integral elasticity relations lead to well-posed elastostatic problems. Elastostatic problems of SDM inflected nano-plates can be solved in terms of nonlocal transverse deflection fields w , for any axisymmetric loading system and boundary condition. An effective solution procedure will be provided in Section 5 .

sections.heading: 4. Strain gradient theory of elasticity for nano-plates
sections.text:
In order to compare the flexural response of SDM nano-plates with the counterpart results of the strain gradient theory of elasticity (SGT), the size-dependent flexure of axisymmetric annular circular nano-plates is formulated utilizing the Reissner variational principle ( Faghidian, 2018a , b ). Employing the first- and second-order gradient tensors in the axisymmetric state, the Reissner functional is introduced as

The set of differential and boundary conditions of equilibrium for the flexure of annular circular nano-plates consistent with the SGT can be equivalently obtained by an application of minimum potential energy principle ( Gousias & Lazopoulos, 2015; Ji et al., 2017; Papargyri-Beskou & Beskos, 2008; Papargyri-Beskou et al., 2010 ).
5. Case studies, numerical illustrations and comparisons
5.1. Case studies
The size-dependent models formulated in the previous sections are adopted to examine the flexural response of plates subjected to a variety of loadings and boundary conditions (BC). Five different case studies will be examined here including annular and circular plates under uniformly distributed loadings per unit area with clamped and simply supported edges as well as simply-supported plates subjected to uniformly distributed couples along the boundary.
For an annular nano-plate with clamped edges under a uniformly distributed load q 0 , the clamped BC on the inner and
outer radii are expressed by
w ( a ) = dw dr ( a ) = 0 , w ( b ) = dw dr ( b ) = 0 (24)
Circular plates are a special case of annular planforms which are free on the internal boundary as the inner radius goes
to zero. Consequently, the classic BC to be prescribed on circular plates with clamped edges are
lim a → 0 M rr ( a ) = lim a → 0 Q r ( a ) = 0 , w ( b ) = dw dr ( b ) = 0 (25)
where Q r represents the shear force defined by ( Timoshenko & Woinowsky-Krieger, 1959 )
Q r = 1 r d dr ( r M rr ) − 1 r M θθ (26)
The classic BC of annular plates with simply supported edges on the inner and outer radii are
w ( a ) = M rr ( a ) = 0 , w ( b ) = M rr ( b ) = 0 (27) The classic BC of circular plates under a uniform load with simply supported edges are
lim a → 0 M rr ( a ) = lim a → 0 Q r ( a ) = 0 , w ( b ) = M rr ( b ) = 0 (28)
Finally, for a circular plate subjected to only uniformly distributed bending couples M̄ along the boundary, the classic BC
are provided by
lim a → 0 M rr ( a ) = lim a → 0 Q r ( a ) = 0 , w ( b ) = 0 , M rr ( b ) = M̄ (29)
In the stress-driven nonlocal integral model, the CBC Eq. (14) in terms of the transverse deflection w are given by
−d 3 w d r 3 ( a ) = − 1

+ d 3 w d r 3 ( b ) = − 1

where the differential conditions of kinematic compatibility Eq. (2) are employed.
Furthermore, the additional constitutive BC to be prescribed on both internal and external radii of nano-plates consistent
with the strain gradient theory of elasticity Eq. (21) 4 are expressed in terms of the transverse deflection w as
M ( 1 ) r r r ( a ) = −D 2 ( d 3 w

where the differential relation of higher-order resultant moment M (1) r r r is utilized as Eq. (22) 3 .
In all of the illustrative results, the following non-dimensional parameters are considered
r̄ = r − a b − a , λ = L c b − a , w̄ ( ̄r ) = w ( r ) w LPT max (32)
where in the case of strain gradient theory L c will be replaced by in the definition of non-dimensional characteristic parameter λ. Hereafter, the acronyms LPT, SDM and SGT denote the local plate theory, stress-driven integral model and the strain gradient theory of elasticity.
Before performing a parametric numerical study, SGT is exploited to detect analytical solutions of simply-supported circular nano-plates subjected to uniformly distributed couples along the boundary. In the absence of distributed transverse load q , the general solution of the homogenous sixth-order differential equation governing the flexure of strain gradient circular nano-plates is expressed by ( Gousias & Lazopoulos, 2015 ),
w SGT ( r ) = 1 + 2 r 2 + 3 I 0 ( r ) + 4 K 0 ( r ) + 5 ln r + 6 r 2 ln r (33)
where I 0 , K 0 are the zero-order modified Bessel functions of the first- and second-kind along with k (k = 1 .. 6) being unknown constants to be computed by suitable boundary conditions. For a circular nano-plate, transverse deflection and curvatures of the plate have to be bounded at the center, consequently 4 = 5 = 6 = 0 . The transverse deflection of the nano-plate can be therefore simplified as
w SGT ( r ) = 1 + 2 r 2 + 3 I 0 ( r ) (34)
For simply-supported nano-plates subjected to uniformly distributed bending couples along the boundary, the classical (kinematic and static) and constitutive boundary conditions in the framework of SGT are given by Eqs. (29) and (31) . Employing these boundary conditions, the transverse deflection of the strain gradient nano-plate w is determined as
w SGT ( r ) = M̄ b 2
2 D ( 1 + ν)
( 1 − ( r
b
)2 ) (35)
It can be interestingly inferred from Eq. (35) that the elastic flexural response of simply-supported SGT nano-plates subjected to uniformly distributed boundary couples is independent of the scale parameter λ and coincides with the one of the local plate theory ( Timoshenko & Woinowsky-Krieger, 1959 ). Unlike the strain gradient elasticity theory, SDM provides a technically significant non-vanishing size-dependent structural response.
5.2. Numerical illustrations and comparisons
The stress-driven nonlocal integral and strain gradient models of elasticity are adopted in order to get numerical assessments of flexural deflections of axisymmetric nano-plates. To examine the effects of the characteristic parameter λ on flexural responses of nano-plates, the ratio of external to internal radius b/a = 3 for annular plates and the Poisson ratio ν = 1 / 4 ( Acierno et al., 2017; Barretta et al., 2017 ) is assumed in all illustrations.
Dependency of the characteristic parameter λ on the non-dimensional maximum deflection w̄ max corresponding to the pure stress-driven integral model and strain gradient theory of elasticity for annular and circular plates under uniform loadings per unit area with clamped and simply supported edges, and simply-supported circular plates subjected to uniformly distributed boundary couples is depicted in Figs. 3–7 . 3D sketches of variations of non-dimensional maximum deflections w̄ versus the non-dimensional variable r̄ and characteristic parameter λ are illustrated in Figs. 8–12 . In all illustrations the non-dimensional scale parameter λ is assumed to range in the interval ]0, 1[.
For annular and circular nano-plates uniformly loaded on the planform, it is noticeably deduced from Figs. 3–6 and 8–11 that both the stress-driven integral and strain gradient models reveal a stiffening behavior of the flexural response in terms of the non-dimensional characteristic parameter λ. The flexural results of both the SDM and SGT models also provide the local solution for vanishing characteristic parameter λ → 0 + .
The numerical pattern in decrease of the elastic flexural deflection of nano-plates with respect to the characteristic parameter is different in SDM and SGT models as a result of profound differences in the fundamental assumptions of the models to capture the size-dependent phenomena. The strain gradient theory of elasticity is essentially established on the postulate that the material response at a point in the continuum is a function of the elastic strain as well as the gradients of various orders, up to a value characterizing the non-simplicity grade of the material and the expected extent of physics to be captured ( Aifantis, 1992 ). The elastic strain field of stress-driven nonlocal theory is presumed to be a functional of the stress field described as integral convolution between the stress field and a suitable averaging kernel.
As it can be interestingly inferred from Figs. 7 and 12 , the strain gradient flexural response of simply supported axisymmetric nano-plates under uniform boundary couples is independent of the scale parameter λ and coincides with the one
of the local plate theory. While the illustrated results in Figs. 7 and 12 reveal that the strain gradient theory is not able to assess size effects, such a behavior is absent in the results associated with the stress-driven nonlocal integral model. The numerical maximum deflections w̄ max evaluated by stress-driven nonlocal integral and strain gradient models of elasticity are collected in Table 1 for the aforementioned case studies.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text:
The main outcomes of the present study may be summarized as follows.
• Size-dependent elastostatic responses of axisymmetric annular nano-plates have been examined by a stress-driven nonlocal integral methodology of elasticity, extending thus the treatment in ( Romano & Barretta, 2017a ) confined to nano-
beams.
• The proposed integral model for axisymmetric elastic nano-plates has been shown to be equivalent to a differential nonlocal problem equipped with constitutive boundary conditions involving the elastic radial curvatures. The corresponding
elastostatic problem of nano-plates is thus conveniently solvable by a simple analytical approach. The solution procedure is applicable to 2D nanostructures subjected to arbitrary axisymmetric loading systems and kinematic boundary conditions. • Size-dependent flexural responses of nano-plates, based on the stress-driven nonlocal model, exhibit a stiffening behavior for increasing nonlocal parameters when compared to the well-known local solution. Such a trend, typical of several
structures for nanotechnological applications, is nowadays acknowledged by the scientific community, as emphasized in recent studies on nanobeams ( Fuschi, Pisano, & Polizzotto, 2019 ). • Flexural responses of stress-driven annular nano-plates have been analytically determined for a variety of loading systems and kinematic boundary conditions. Nonlocal effects have been then compared with those obtained by the strain gradient
elasticity model developed by Reissner’s variational principle.
• It has been shown that the strain gradient model can provide structural responses which are independent of the scale parameter. Hence, they could be of limited technical interest. The stress-driven approach can instead be advantageously
employed for the design of modern nano-structured components of Nano-Electro-Mechanical Systems (NEMS).
Supplementary materials
Supplementary material associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi: 10.1016/j.ijengsci.2019.01.
003 .

referenceMentions.context: An enhanced Eringen differential law ( Barretta, Feo, Luciano, Marotti de Sciarra, & Penna, 2016a,b ) has been also employed for studying torsion ( Apuzzo et al., 2017a ) and flexure of nano-beams ( Demir & Civalek, 2017 ). Elastic solids reinforced with bidirectional fibers ( Kim & Zeidi, 2018 ), pure bending problems of beams ( Lurie & Solyaev, 2018 ), flexure of slender nano-beams ( Barretta, Brcic, Canadija, Luciano, & Marotti de Sciarra, 2017 ), free vibrations of nano-beams ( Hadi, ZamaniNejad, & Hosseini, 2018 ) and flexoelectric curved micro-beams ( Qi, Huang, Fu, Zhou, & Jiang, 2018 ) have been furthermore inspected by strain gradient elasticity laws. The modified couple stress theory has been likewise exploited to estimate dynamic responses ( Attia & Abdel Rahman, 2018; Ghayesh, 2018 , 2019; Ghayesh & Farokhi, 2018 ) and stability of nano-structures ( Jiao & Alavi, 2018; Taati, 2018 ). Consistent with the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity model, flexure ( Li, Tang, & Hu, 2018b ), vibrations ( Lu, Guo, & Zhao, 2017 ) of nano-beams, tension of nano-rods ( Zhu & Li, 2017a , b ), dynamics of nano-tubes ( Ghayesh & Farajpour, 2018; Ghayesh, Farokhi, & Farajpour, 2019 ) and wave propagation and vibrations of porous nano-tubes ( She, Ren, Yuan, & Xiao, 2018a , b ) as well as curved nanotubes ( She, Yuan, Karami, Ren, & Xiao, 2019 ) have been explored. In the framework of the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory, the Reissner variational principle has been lately proposed ( Faghidian, 2018a ) and employed to introduce the Reissner beam model ( Faghidian, 2018b ). A second-order integro-differential nonlocal theory was also contributed by a thermodynamic approach ( Faghidian, 2018c ) to include higher-order strain gradient effects within Eringen integral nonlocal theory. The modified nonlocal strain gradient model of elasticity has been established by Barretta and Marotti de Sciarra (2018) introducing the appropriate constitutive boundary conditions to be prescribed to close the constitutive model for bounded nano-structures.

An enhanced Eringen differential law ( Barretta, Feo, Luciano, Marotti de Sciarra, & Penna, 2016a,b ) has been also employed for studying torsion ( Apuzzo et al., 2017a ) and flexure of nano-beams ( Demir & Civalek, 2017 ). Elastic solids reinforced with bidirectional fibers ( Kim & Zeidi, 2018 ), pure bending problems of beams ( Lurie & Solyaev, 2018 ), flexure of slender nano-beams ( Barretta, Brcic, Canadija, Luciano, & Marotti de Sciarra, 2017 ), free vibrations of nano-beams ( Hadi, ZamaniNejad, & Hosseini, 2018 ) and flexoelectric curved micro-beams ( Qi, Huang, Fu, Zhou, & Jiang, 2018 ) have been furthermore inspected by strain gradient elasticity laws. The modified couple stress theory has been likewise exploited to estimate dynamic responses ( Attia & Abdel Rahman, 2018; Ghayesh, 2018 , 2019; Ghayesh & Farokhi, 2018 ) and stability of nano-structures ( Jiao & Alavi, 2018; Taati, 2018 ). Consistent with the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity model, flexure ( Li, Tang, & Hu, 2018b ), vibrations ( Lu, Guo, & Zhao, 2017 ) of nano-beams, tension of nano-rods ( Zhu & Li, 2017a , b ), dynamics of nano-tubes ( Ghayesh & Farajpour, 2018; Ghayesh, Farokhi, & Farajpour, 2019 ) and wave propagation and vibrations of porous nano-tubes ( She, Ren, Yuan, & Xiao, 2018a , b ) as well as curved nanotubes ( She, Yuan, Karami, Ren, & Xiao, 2019 ) have been explored. In the framework of the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory, the Reissner variational principle has been lately proposed ( Faghidian, 2018a ) and employed to introduce the Reissner beam model ( Faghidian, 2018b ). A second-order integro-differential nonlocal theory was also contributed by a thermodynamic approach ( Faghidian, 2018c ) to include higher-order strain gradient effects within Eringen integral nonlocal theory. The modified nonlocal strain gradient model of elasticity has been established by Barretta and Marotti de Sciarra (2018) introducing the appropriate constitutive boundary conditions to be prescribed to close the constitutive model for bounded nano-structures. Such a theory has been effectively adopted to examine axial and flexural free vibrations of Bernoulli–Euler nano-beams ( Apuzzo, Barretta, Faghidian, Luciano, & Marotti de Sciarra, 2018a ). A variety of size-dependent theories of elasticity have been employed in literature to study nano-plates subjected to flexure including the Eringen differential nonlocal model ( Despotovic, 2018; Khaniki & Hosseini-Hashemi, 2017; Li, Liu, Cheng, & Fan, 2017; Srividhya, Raghu, Rajagopal, & Reddy, 2018 ), strain gradient theory ( Gousias & Lazopoulos, 2015; Ji, Li, & Zhou, 2017; Lazopoulos, 20 04, 20 09; Mirsalehi, Azhari, & Amoushahi, 2017; Mousavi & Paavola, 2014; Papargyri-Beskou & Beskos, 2008; Papargyri-Beskou, Giannakopoulos, & Beskos, 2010 ), modified couple stress theory ( Barati & Shahverdi, 2017; Farokhi & Ghayesh, 2018; Farokhi, Ghayesh, Gholipour, & Tavallaeinejad, 2017; Rahaeifard & Mojahedi, 2017 ) and nonlocal strain gradient laws ( Ebrahimi, Barati, & Dabbagh, 2016; Lu, Guo, & Zhao, 2018; Shahverdi & Barati, 2017 ). Reviews on the mechanics of nanostructures have been provided in ( Farajpour, Ghayesh, & Farokhi, 2018; Ghayesh & Farajpour, 2019 ). According to the strain-driven Eringen integral model (EIM), the stress field is the convolution of the elastic strain field with an appropriate kernel function ( Eringen, 1983 ). In Eringen’s purely nonlocal problems defined on unbounded domains, the integral convolution is a Fredholm equation of the first type. It can be replaced with a more convenient differential equation, named Eringen differential nonlocal model (EDM), due to tacit fulfillment of vanishing constitutive boundary conditions at infinity. However, for nanostructures of applicative problems (defined on bounded domains), EDM is not equivalent to EIM but suitable strain-driven constitutive boundary conditions (CBC) have to be prescribed to ensure equivalence ( Romano & Barretta, 2016 ). Nevertheless, CBC conflict with equilibrium requirements and therefore these nonlocal problems are ill-posed ( Romano, Barretta, Diaco, & Marotti de Sciarra, 2017a ). Ill-posedness of elastostatic nonlocal problems governed by EIM was comprehensively discussed by Romano et al. (2017a, 2017b, 2018 ) demonstrating that EIM nonlocal problems of nano-mechanics do not admit solution for any positive value of the nonlocal parameter. A mixture made of Eringen integral model (MEIM) is a convex combination of local and EIM nonlocal phases, that is a combination with non-negative scalar coefficients summing to unity. The MEIM was adopted to resolve the ill-posedness of strain-driven nonlocal problems. However, MEIM reveals singular behaviors as the mixture is approaching the nonlocal EIM phase, thus the ill-posedness of EIM cannot be utterly removed ( Romano et al., 2017b, 2018 ). A stress-driven nonlocal integral model (SDM) was recently introduced to nano-beams by Romano and Barretta (2017a) to resolve inconsistencies of EIM.

An enhanced Eringen differential law ( Barretta, Feo, Luciano, Marotti de Sciarra, & Penna, 2016a,b ) has been also employed for studying torsion ( Apuzzo et al., 2017a ) and flexure of nano-beams ( Demir & Civalek, 2017 ). Elastic solids reinforced with bidirectional fibers ( Kim & Zeidi, 2018 ), pure bending problems of beams ( Lurie & Solyaev, 2018 ), flexure of slender nano-beams ( Barretta, Brcic, Canadija, Luciano, & Marotti de Sciarra, 2017 ), free vibrations of nano-beams ( Hadi, ZamaniNejad, & Hosseini, 2018 ) and flexoelectric curved micro-beams ( Qi, Huang, Fu, Zhou, & Jiang, 2018 ) have been furthermore inspected by strain gradient elasticity laws. The modified couple stress theory has been likewise exploited to estimate dynamic responses ( Attia & Abdel Rahman, 2018; Ghayesh, 2018 , 2019; Ghayesh & Farokhi, 2018 ) and stability of nano-structures ( Jiao & Alavi, 2018; Taati, 2018 ). Consistent with the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity model, flexure ( Li, Tang, & Hu, 2018b ), vibrations ( Lu, Guo, & Zhao, 2017 ) of nano-beams, tension of nano-rods ( Zhu & Li, 2017a , b ), dynamics of nano-tubes ( Ghayesh & Farajpour, 2018; Ghayesh, Farokhi, & Farajpour, 2019 ) and wave propagation and vibrations of porous nano-tubes ( She, Ren, Yuan, & Xiao, 2018a , b ) as well as curved nanotubes ( She, Yuan, Karami, Ren, & Xiao, 2019 ) have been explored. In the framework of the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory, the Reissner variational principle has been lately proposed ( Faghidian, 2018a ) and employed to introduce the Reissner beam model ( Faghidian, 2018b ). A second-order integro-differential nonlocal theory was also contributed by a thermodynamic approach ( Faghidian, 2018c ) to include higher-order strain gradient effects within Eringen integral nonlocal theory. The modified nonlocal strain gradient model of elasticity has been established by Barretta and Marotti de Sciarra (2018) introducing the appropriate constitutive boundary conditions to be prescribed to close the constitutive model for bounded nano-structures. Such a theory has been effectively adopted to examine axial and flexural free vibrations of Bernoulli–Euler nano-beams ( Apuzzo, Barretta, Faghidian, Luciano, & Marotti de Sciarra, 2018a ). A variety of size-dependent theories of elasticity have been employed in literature to study nano-plates subjected to flexure including the Eringen differential nonlocal model ( Despotovic, 2018; Khaniki & Hosseini-Hashemi, 2017; Li, Liu, Cheng, & Fan, 2017; Srividhya, Raghu, Rajagopal, & Reddy, 2018 ), strain gradient theory ( Gousias & Lazopoulos, 2015; Ji, Li, & Zhou, 2017; Lazopoulos, 20 04, 20 09; Mirsalehi, Azhari, & Amoushahi, 2017; Mousavi & Paavola, 2014; Papargyri-Beskou & Beskos, 2008; Papargyri-Beskou, Giannakopoulos, & Beskos, 2010 ), modified couple stress theory ( Barati & Shahverdi, 2017; Farokhi & Ghayesh, 2018; Farokhi, Ghayesh, Gholipour, & Tavallaeinejad, 2017; Rahaeifard & Mojahedi, 2017 ) and nonlocal strain gradient laws ( Ebrahimi, Barati, & Dabbagh, 2016; Lu, Guo, & Zhao, 2018; Shahverdi & Barati, 2017 ). Reviews on the mechanics of nanostructures have been provided in ( Farajpour, Ghayesh, & Farokhi, 2018; Ghayesh & Farajpour, 2019 ). According to the strain-driven Eringen integral model (EIM), the stress field is the convolution of the elastic strain field with an appropriate kernel function ( Eringen, 1983 ). In Eringen’s purely nonlocal problems defined on unbounded domains, the integral convolution is a Fredholm equation of the first type. It can be replaced with a more convenient differential equation, named Eringen differential nonlocal model (EDM), due to tacit fulfillment of vanishing constitutive boundary conditions at infinity. However, for nanostructures of applicative problems (defined on bounded domains), EDM is not equivalent to EIM but suitable strain-driven constitutive boundary conditions (CBC) have to be prescribed to ensure equivalence ( Romano & Barretta, 2016 ). Nevertheless, CBC conflict with equilibrium requirements and therefore these nonlocal problems are ill-posed ( Romano, Barretta, Diaco, & Marotti de Sciarra, 2017a ). Ill-posedness of elastostatic nonlocal problems governed by EIM was comprehensively discussed by Romano et al. (2017a, 2017b, 2018 ) demonstrating that EIM nonlocal problems of nano-mechanics do not admit solution for any positive value of the nonlocal parameter. A mixture made of Eringen integral model (MEIM) is a convex combination of local and EIM nonlocal phases, that is a combination with non-negative scalar coefficients summing to unity. The MEIM was adopted to resolve the ill-posedness of strain-driven nonlocal problems. However, MEIM reveals singular behaviors as the mixture is approaching the nonlocal EIM phase, thus the ill-posedness of EIM cannot be utterly removed ( Romano et al., 2017b, 2018 ). A stress-driven nonlocal integral model (SDM) was recently introduced to nano-beams by Romano and Barretta (2017a) to resolve inconsistencies of EIM. Properties and merits of the well-posed SDM in comparison with strain-driven nonlocal models have been addressed in ( Romano and Barretta, 2017a , b ). The consistent SDM approach has been effectively exploited to analyze and describe size-dependent static and dynamic behaviors of inflected Bernoulli-Euler ( Apuzzo, Barretta, Luciano, Marotti de Sciarra, & Penna, 2017b; Barretta et al., 2018a , b,c,d,e; Mahmoudpour, Hosseini-Hashemi, & Faghidian, 2018 ) and Timoshenko elastic nano-beams ( Barretta, Luciano, Marotti de Sciarra, & Ruta, 2018f ). A two-phase stress-driven constitutive mixture has been also recently proposed by Barretta Fabbrocino, Luciano, & Marotti de Sciarra (2018g) to examine size-dependent flexural behaviour of functionally graded nano-beams.

An enhanced Eringen differential law ( Barretta, Feo, Luciano, Marotti de Sciarra, & Penna, 2016a,b ) has been also employed for studying torsion ( Apuzzo et al., 2017a ) and flexure of nano-beams ( Demir & Civalek, 2017 ). Elastic solids reinforced with bidirectional fibers ( Kim & Zeidi, 2018 ), pure bending problems of beams ( Lurie & Solyaev, 2018 ), flexure of slender nano-beams ( Barretta, Brcic, Canadija, Luciano, & Marotti de Sciarra, 2017 ), free vibrations of nano-beams ( Hadi, ZamaniNejad, & Hosseini, 2018 ) and flexoelectric curved micro-beams ( Qi, Huang, Fu, Zhou, & Jiang, 2018 ) have been furthermore inspected by strain gradient elasticity laws. The modified couple stress theory has been likewise exploited to estimate dynamic responses ( Attia & Abdel Rahman, 2018; Ghayesh, 2018 , 2019; Ghayesh & Farokhi, 2018 ) and stability of nano-structures ( Jiao & Alavi, 2018; Taati, 2018 ). Consistent with the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity model, flexure ( Li, Tang, & Hu, 2018b ), vibrations ( Lu, Guo, & Zhao, 2017 ) of nano-beams, tension of nano-rods ( Zhu & Li, 2017a , b ), dynamics of nano-tubes ( Ghayesh & Farajpour, 2018; Ghayesh, Farokhi, & Farajpour, 2019 ) and wave propagation and vibrations of porous nano-tubes ( She, Ren, Yuan, & Xiao, 2018a , b ) as well as curved nanotubes ( She, Yuan, Karami, Ren, & Xiao, 2019 ) have been explored. In the framework of the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory, the Reissner variational principle has been lately proposed ( Faghidian, 2018a ) and employed to introduce the Reissner beam model ( Faghidian, 2018b ). A second-order integro-differential nonlocal theory was also contributed by a thermodynamic approach ( Faghidian, 2018c ) to include higher-order strain gradient effects within Eringen integral nonlocal theory. The modified nonlocal strain gradient model of elasticity has been established by Barretta and Marotti de Sciarra (2018) introducing the appropriate constitutive boundary conditions to be prescribed to close the constitutive model for bounded nano-structures. Such a theory has been effectively adopted to examine axial and flexural free vibrations of Bernoulli–Euler nano-beams ( Apuzzo, Barretta, Faghidian, Luciano, & Marotti de Sciarra, 2018a ). A variety of size-dependent theories of elasticity have been employed in literature to study nano-plates subjected to flexure including the Eringen differential nonlocal model ( Despotovic, 2018; Khaniki & Hosseini-Hashemi, 2017; Li, Liu, Cheng, & Fan, 2017; Srividhya, Raghu, Rajagopal, & Reddy, 2018 ), strain gradient theory ( Gousias & Lazopoulos, 2015; Ji, Li, & Zhou, 2017; Lazopoulos, 20 04, 20 09; Mirsalehi, Azhari, & Amoushahi, 2017; Mousavi & Paavola, 2014; Papargyri-Beskou & Beskos, 2008; Papargyri-Beskou, Giannakopoulos, & Beskos, 2010 ), modified couple stress theory ( Barati & Shahverdi, 2017; Farokhi & Ghayesh, 2018; Farokhi, Ghayesh, Gholipour, & Tavallaeinejad, 2017; Rahaeifard & Mojahedi, 2017 ) and nonlocal strain gradient laws ( Ebrahimi, Barati, & Dabbagh, 2016; Lu, Guo, & Zhao, 2018; Shahverdi & Barati, 2017 ). Reviews on the mechanics of nanostructures have been provided in ( Farajpour, Ghayesh, & Farokhi, 2018; Ghayesh & Farajpour, 2019 ). According to the strain-driven Eringen integral model (EIM), the stress field is the convolution of the elastic strain field with an appropriate kernel function ( Eringen, 1983 ). In Eringen’s purely nonlocal problems defined on unbounded domains, the integral convolution is a Fredholm equation of the first type. It can be replaced with a more convenient differential equation, named Eringen differential nonlocal model (EDM), due to tacit fulfillment of vanishing constitutive boundary conditions at infinity. However, for nanostructures of applicative problems (defined on bounded domains), EDM is not equivalent to EIM but suitable strain-driven constitutive boundary conditions (CBC) have to be prescribed to ensure equivalence ( Romano & Barretta, 2016 ). Nevertheless, CBC conflict with equilibrium requirements and therefore these nonlocal problems are ill-posed ( Romano, Barretta, Diaco, & Marotti de Sciarra, 2017a ). Ill-posedness of elastostatic nonlocal problems governed by EIM was comprehensively discussed by Romano et al. (2017a, 2017b, 2018 ) demonstrating that EIM nonlocal problems of nano-mechanics do not admit solution for any positive value of the nonlocal parameter. A mixture made of Eringen integral model (MEIM) is a convex combination of local and EIM nonlocal phases, that is a combination with non-negative scalar coefficients summing to unity. The MEIM was adopted to resolve the ill-posedness of strain-driven nonlocal problems. However, MEIM reveals singular behaviors as the mixture is approaching the nonlocal EIM phase, thus the ill-posedness of EIM cannot be utterly removed ( Romano et al., 2017b, 2018 ). A stress-driven nonlocal integral model (SDM) was recently introduced to nano-beams by Romano and Barretta (2017a) to resolve inconsistencies of EIM. Properties and merits of the well-posed SDM in comparison with strain-driven nonlocal models have been addressed in ( Romano and Barretta, 2017a , b ). The consistent SDM approach has been effectively exploited to analyze and describe size-dependent static and dynamic behaviors of inflected Bernoulli-Euler ( Apuzzo, Barretta, Luciano, Marotti de Sciarra, & Penna, 2017b; Barretta et al., 2018a , b,c,d,e; Mahmoudpour, Hosseini-Hashemi, & Faghidian, 2018 ) and Timoshenko elastic nano-beams ( Barretta, Luciano, Marotti de Sciarra, & Ruta, 2018f ). A two-phase stress-driven constitutive mixture has been also recently proposed by Barretta Fabbrocino, Luciano, & Marotti de Sciarra (2018g) to examine size-dependent flexural behaviour of functionally graded nano-beams. Such a localnonlocal mixture is a convex combination of local and nonlocal phases of stress-driven type ( Romano & Barretta, 2017a ). The mixture made of stress-driven nonlocal integral model (MSDM) has been then employed for dynamic axial and torsional analyses of nano-beams ( Apuzzo et al., 2019 ). Nowadays, SDM and MSDM provide viable methodologies to design and optimize nano-structural elements of new-generation. In the present paper, axisymmetric flexure of nano-plates is formulated by proposing a stress-driven nonlocal integral model which generalizes to nano-plates the methodology presented in Romano & Barretta (2017a) for beams.

The stress-driven nonlocal integral model (SDM), proposed by Romano and Barretta (2017a) for nano-beams, is extended in this section to capture size effects in axisymmetric annular elastic nano-plates.
Following the strategy exploited in Barretta & Marotti de Sciarra (2018) , Prop.

metadata.abstractText: The stress-driven nonlocal integral model of elasticity for 1D nano-structures (Romano & Barretta, 2017a) is extended in this paper to Kirchhoff axisymmetric nano-plates. The nonlocal formulation, relating elastic principal flexural curvatures and moments, provides an effective methodology to assess size effects in 2D nano-structures. The associated elastostatic problem of nano-plates is conveniently expressed by differential relations equipped with constitutive boundary conditions involving nonlocal curvature fields. The proposed approach is illustrated by examining case-studies of engineering interest. In particular, nonlocal displacement solutions of axisymmetric nano-plates are detected for a variety of loading systems and kinematic boundary conditions. Merits and implications of the stressdriven strategy are elucidated by comparing the achieved results with those of the strain gradient model of elasticity generated by Reissner’s variational principle. The outcomes can be useful for design and optimization of plate-like components of ground-breaking NanoElectro-Mechanical-Systems (NEMS). © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
